newsitem.title: USA: MGE spring wheat follows other markets to end up.
newsitem.headline: MGE spring wheat follows other markets to end up.

text.p: MGE spring wheat futures were mostly a follower of other wheat markets throughout the day, but a late surge enabled spring wheat to close relatively higher than their CBOT and KCBT counterparts, traders said.
U.S. wheat gained on hopes of exports, triggered not only by a stronger-than-expected weekly export sales report but also by the news that India will need to import two million tonnes of wheat.
But gains in MGE spring wheat were limited during the first half of the session by hedge-selling related to an increase in country movement.
Nonetheless, a late buying surge helped March spring wheat break through Wednesday's resistance at $3.85-1/2 per bushel.
Benson-Quinn, CIS, Atwood/Peavey and Country Hedging each sold around 800,000 March bushels, and traders said most of this was hedge-related.
Wilson reportedly bought two million March bushels on the intermarket spread with Kansas City. CIS bought 1.6 million March -- much of it in the session's second half.
MGE spring wheat closed 2-1/2 to eight cents per bushel higher, with Dec up 2-1/2 cents at $4.19. March gained 6-1/2 cents to settle at $3.87-1/4.
MGE barley futures did not trade.
